Award.AwardTitle: Academic Integrity Management (AIM) of a collaborative three year computer science degree program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

This project is being supported under a special funding focus for STEP, "Graduate 10K+," an activity of the National Science Foundation, supported in part by donations from the Intel Foundation and the GE Foundation, to stimulate comprehensive action at universities and colleges to help increase the annual number of new B.S. graduates in engineering and computer science by 10,000 over the next decade.

California State University Monterey Bay (CSUMB) and Hartnell College have assessed the challenges facing underrepresented and disadvantaged students seeking educational opportunities in computer science. Given the obstacles and the resources available, CSUMB and Hartnell committed to developing a three-year bachelor's degree option coupled with significant student support structures and financial assistance as a way to improve outcomes.

The project is incorporating the following features:
o Collaboration between a 2- and 4- year college, in which students are completing the first 1.5 years of the program primarily at Hartnell and the final 1.5 years primarily at CSUMB;
o Improving the college-readiness of students through a summer bridge program;
o Organizing students into cohorts that are maintained from enrollment through transfer and graduation;
o Providing ongoing academic support through identification of academic needs and provision of support services;
o Delivering career development support through workshops and internship placements;
o Providing scholarship support that eliminates the need for students to seek outside employment.
o Executing a detailed evaluation plan with an external evaluator to study the performance of project components.

Additionally, the project has secured a commitment from the Matsui Foundation, a local non-profit organization, to provide significant funding that supports full scholarships for students.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in its implementation of a three-year Bachelor of Science degree program in computer science/information technology (CSIT) to successfully attract, retain, transfer, and graduate students from disadvantaged and underrepresented populations. The project incorporates three critical components: (1) an accelerated three-year time frame, (2) collaboration between a community college and a university, and (3) a cohort-based learning model.

The project's broader impacts are felt in the increased access to computer science and success of 150 underrepresented and disadvantaged students, through the combination of an accelerated program, student scholarships, student cohorts, and leveraging computer science support programs. Dissemination of evaluation data and best practices from this project are also providing substantial information to education leaders to duplicate collaborative three or four year pathways that utilize resources of multiple institutions to increase retention and graduation of students in computer science and STEM.

Performance_Institution.Name: California State University Monterey Bay Foundation

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has implemented and documented a cohort-based model with three critical components: (1) an accelerated three-year time frame, (2) collaboration between a community college and a university, and (3) a cohort-based learning model. This one of its kind program has demonstrated substantial improvement of the key metrics of success for first generation, low income and URM students and has been recognized as one of the top tier innovative education programs in California. A publication documenting this model received the best paper recognition at ACM SIGCSE 2018 conference.

The work completed under this project has directly impacted over 160 students who have participated in the program, as well as had a significant impact on the overall quality of the CS programs at Hartnell and Cal State Monterey Bay by strengthening the community college to university pipeline, attracting new industry partners, and building academic and extra-curricular support programming that is available to all students. It was the catalyst for launching a similar 4-year, cohort-based pathway for incoming CS freshmen at Cal State Monterey Bay that has since included over 100 participants, and is being replicated in Southern California with cohorts starting at El Camino College and at California State University Dominguez Hills in fall 2019.

Notable improvements in key metrics evaluated by the program include:

  • A significant increase in the capacity of the CS program at CSUMB. CSUMB is one of the smallest campuses in the 23-campus CSU system that serves almost 500K students.  However, it produced 1/17 of all CSU CS graduates in Spring 2018.

  • A significant demographic shift in CSUMB CS graduates. Prior to launching its CS cohort programs, in Spring 2013, CSUMB produced 1/34 of all Hispanic CS graduates from across the CSU and 1/30 of all female CS graduates. As of Spring 2017, CSUMB produced 1/13 of all Hispanic CS graduates and 1/11 of female CS graduates in the CSU system.

  • 184 students completed CS internships in summer 2015, 2016, 2017, and 2018. Organizations include Adobe, Allstate, Amazon, Apple, Atlassian, BofA, Cisco, Code2040, Driscoll, eBay, Facebook, Google, Intuit, NASA Ames, Nationwide, Salesforce, Uber, VmWare, and Zynga.

  • Improved completion and transfer rates from community college to university. The average 1.5 year Associate degree completion rate and transfer rate for participating students is 83.2% (134 out of 161 cohort students).

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2019
Modified by: Sathya Narayanan

Notable improvements in key metrics evaluated by the program include: A significant increase in the capacity of the CS program at CSUMB. CSUMB is one of the smallest campuses in the 23-campus CSU system that serves almost 500K students. However, it produced 1/17 of all CSU CS graduates in Spring 2018. A significant demographic shift in CSUMB CS graduates. Prior to launching its CS cohort programs, in Spring 2013, CSUMB produced 1/34 of all Hispanic CS graduates from across the CSU and 1/30 of all female CS graduates. As of Spring 2017, CSUMB produced 1/13 of all Hispanic CS graduates and 1/11 of female CS graduates in the CSU system. 184 students completed CS internships in summer 2015, 2016, 2017, and 2018. Organizations include Adobe, Allstate, Amazon, Apple, Atlassian, BofA, Cisco, Code2040, Driscoll, eBay, Facebook, Google, Intuit, NASA Ames, Nationwide, Salesforce, Uber, VmWare, and Zynga.
